keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021 and later arrested in 2025 for threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, with text messages indicating a clear intent to kill.
The threat was serious enough for law enforcement to describe it as credible and with a clear intention to carry out the attack.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching the Capitol on January 6, 2021.
Trump's pardon of Moynihan and over 1,000 others has drawn criticism for enabling former rioters to remain free and reoffend.

The incident reflects a broader pattern of political violence in the U.S. in 2025, including the killing of Democratic lawmakers in Minnesota and the assassination of conservative activist Charlie Kirk in Utah.
Hakeem Jeffries, a top Democratic leader and potential future Speaker, expressed gratitude for law enforcement intervention and criticized the pardon of violent individuals.
Moynihan is currently being held in Poughkeepsie and is scheduled to appear in court on October 23, 2025.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by former President Donald Trump for his role in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested and charged with making a credible death threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, with text messages expressing a clear intent to kill him. He was previously sentenced to 21 months in prison for breaching the Capitol and taking photos of lawmakers. The incident underscores the ongoing concern over political violence in the U.S., especially after the pardoning of rioters. This case is relevant not only because of the threat itself but also because it reflects broader criticism of the Trump administration’s pardon policy, which has enabled former rioters to reoffend. The case also places Moynihan in a broader context of rising political violence in 2025, including the killing of Charlie Kirk in Utah and the attack on Democratic lawmakers in Minnesota.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
